findings.title: Arithmetic Operations Overflow and Underflow
findings.description: Values should be checked before performing arithmetic operations to prevent overflows and underflows.

findings.title: Explicit conversion of types should be checked to prevent unexpected results
findings.description: Ensure explicit type conversions are properly handled to avoid unexpected behavior.

findings.title: Precision Loss in Division and Multiplication
findings.description: Integer division should not be done before multiplication to prevent loss of precision.

findings.title: State changing functions that loop over unbounded data structures should not be used
findings.description: This finding highlights the potential risk of using state-changing functions that iterate over unbounded data structures, which can lead to denial-of-service attacks.

findings.title: Unexpected revert should not make the whole smart contract unusable
findings.description: The smart contract should be designed to handle unexpected reverts without becoming completely unusable.

findings.title: Strict equalities should not cause the function to be unusable
findings.description: The function should remain usable even when strict equalities are encountered.

findings.title: Function return values should be checked to handle different results
findings.description: The function does not check its return values, which can lead to unexpected behavior and potential security vulnerabilities.

findings.title: Privileged functions or modifications of critical states should be logged
findings.description: Critical state changes and privileged function calls should be properly logged to ensure transparency and accountability.

findings.title: Modifier should not skip function execution without reverting
findings.description: Modifiers should always revert if they do not execute a function to maintain consistency and prevent unexpected behavior.

findings.title: The business logic implementation should correspond to the business design
findings.description: The implementation of business logic should align with the intended business design to prevent unintended behavior or outcomes.

findings.title: Measures should be implemented to prevent undesired effects from the ordering of transactions
findings.description: The business logic implementation should ensure that the ordering of transactions does not lead to unintended consequences.

findings.title: msg.value should not be used in loop iteration
findings.description: Using msg.value in a loop can lead to unintended behavior and potential security vulnerabilities.

findings.title: Result from random value generation should not be predictable
findings.description: The result of random value generation should be unpredictable to prevent potential attacks.

findings.title: Spot price should not be used as a data source for price oracles
findings.description: Using spot prices as a data source for price oracles may lead to inaccurate or manipulated price feeds.

findings.title: Timestamp should not be used to execute critical functions
findings.description: Critical functions should not rely on timestamp values as they can be manipulated by miners.

findings.title: Plain sensitive data should not be stored on-chain
findings.description: Sensitive data such as private keys, passwords, or other confidential information should not be stored directly on the blockchain for security and privacy reasons.

findings.title: Modification of array state should not be done by value
findings.description: Array state modification should be done by reference to prevent unintended behavior and potential security risks.

findings.title: State variable should not be used without being initialized
findings.description: Using uninitialized state variables can lead to unpredictable behavior and potential security vulnerabilities.

findings.title: Unknown external components should not be invoked
findings.description: Invoking unknown external components can lead to unintended behavior and potential security risks.

findings.title: Funds should not be approved or transferred to unknown accounts
findings.description: Transferring funds to unknown accounts can lead to unintended loss of assets.

findings.title: Reentrant calling should not negatively affect the contract states
findings.description: Reentrant calling can potentially lead to unintended changes or exploitation of the smart contract's state.

findings.title: Vulnerable or outdated components should not be used in the smart contract
findings.description: The usage of vulnerable or outdated components can lead to security vulnerabilities and potential exploits in the smart contract.

findings.title: Use of Upgradable Smart Contracts
findings.description: Using upgradable smart contracts can make them untrustworthy as the contract logic can be modified by the owner anytime.

findings.title: Delegatecall should not be used on untrusted contracts
findings.description: N/A

findings.title: Use of Upgradable Contract Design
findings.description: The logic of the affected contract can be arbitrarily changed, allowing the proxy owner to perform malicious actions.
